references: Remarkably, as demonstrated in Fig.                  7                .i/Fig.                  7                .i, the experiment exhibited a consistent increase in                                   R                         ‚Äã                                   (                            y                            )                                                                            ùëÖ                            ùë¶                                       R(y)                       and a decrease in                                   R                         ‚Äã                                   (                                       y                               ‚ãÜ                                      )                                                                            ùëÖ                                       superscript                               ùë¶                               ‚ãÜ                                                 R(y^{\star})                       after                                   1000                         ‚àº                         1500                                                 similar-to                            1000                            1500                                       1000\sim 1500                       epochs, indicative of the enhanced capability of the sentinel to generate nontoxic responses despite provocations. In Fig.                  7                .ii/Fig.                  7                .ii, the consistent decrease in                                   R                         mae                                                 subscript                            ùëÖ                            mae                                       R_{\mathrm{mae}}                       also suggests that the larger model size does not impede the fine-tuning process of the red team-sentinel framework. Furthermore, in Tab.                  1                , we showcase several sample responses of                          y                               ùë¶                              y                       and                                   y                         ‚ãÜ                                                 superscript                            ùë¶                            ‚ãÜ                                       y^{\star}                       produced by the           GPT-3.5-Turbo          model. Some text is uncompleted because the maximum generated tokens for                                   œÄ                         r                                                 subscript                            ùúã                            ùëü                                       \pi_{r}                       ,                                   œÄ                         s                                                 subscript                            ùúã                            ùë†                                       \pi_{s}                       and                                   œÄ                         t                                                 subscript                            ùúã                            ùë°                                       \pi_{t}                       are limited to                          20                               20                              20                       ,                          20                               20                              20                       and                          30                               30                              30                       , respectively. It is noteworthy that when using the modified instruction prompt                                   x                         ‚ãÜ                                                 superscript                            ùë•                            ‚ãÜ                                       x^{\star}                       with a sentinel, the generated response                                   y                         ‚ãÜ                                                 superscript                            ùë¶                            ‚ãÜ                                       y^{\star}                       shows a significantly lower probability of toxicity. Conversely, when the sentinel prompt is not used, the score for                          y                               ùë¶                              y                       is high. This emphasizes the generalizability of our framework to larger targets and the effectiveness of the sentinel in reducing the toxicity of scaled up LLMs.

references: Using the script provided in the TRL toxicity repository, we compare our method to           direct detoxification          on the           wiki_toxic          evaluation dataset. The baselines are pretrained           GPT          s of different sizes, and their detoxified versions fine-tuned on           RealToxicityPrompts                (             Gehman et¬†al., 2020b,            )          dataset. Instead of tuning the victims directly with toxic prompts, we employ the sentinel                                   œÄ                         s                                                 subscript                            ùúã                            ùë†                                       \pi_{s}                       as the prefix model before target models and only tune                                   œÄ                         s                                                 subscript                            ùúã                            ùë†                                       \pi_{s}                       with PPO. No red team in this experiment since           (             Gehman et¬†al., 2020b,            )          is already toxic. We initialize                                   œÄ                         s                                                 subscript                            ùúã                            ùë†                                       \pi_{s}                       as           GPT-Neo-125M          . For models without a sentinel, we allow a maximum of                          30                               30                              30                       new tokens as output. For sentinel-assisted models, we restrict                          15                               15                              15                       maximum tokens for both the sentinel and target models, then concatenate the outputs for training/eval. We measure the toxicity score of outputs using the toxicity metric of the huggingface           evaluate          . Detailed parameter configurations are in Tab.                  9                , Appendix                  D                . We report the toxicity score of                          400                               400                              400                       sampled examples in Tab.                  2                . Sentinel-assisted models have better capabilities in reducing the toxicity score of generated text compared to direct-detoxified counterparts. The score gaps between our methods and baselines are clear across all model sizes, while for directly detoxified ones, the gaps are clear for smaller models but less so for the 6B model.

references: Results.          As shown in Tab.                  3                , the sentinel model, especially when trained with the red team interaction framework (           +Sentinel&RedTeam          ), is effective at reducing the toxicity of generated text across all tested language models while preserving or even improving overall usefulness for the smaller models. For           GPT-Neo-2.7B          and           GPT-J-6B          , the sentinel trained with the red team reduces toxicity by 23.5% and 31.8%, respectively, compared to the base models, while also improving average usefulness scores by 2.1% and 6.0%. This is driven by substantial gains in answer relevancy that outweigh minor drops in correctness. However, for the larger           Llama2-7B-Chat          model, while the sentinel achieves an 43.8% reduction in toxicity, it appears to have a detrimental effect on correctness (-6.6%) and relevancy (-4.6%) that results in only slight 0.5% increment in overall usefulness compared to the base model. This suggests that while the sentinel is effective at mitigating toxicity, it still inevitably bring in noise that could affect the quality of final answers, especially for larger models trained with sufficiently many data.

references: Setup.          In this section, we enable the training of both Eq.¬†(                  2                ) and (                  3                ), and explore the capabilities of the red team-sentinel interaction in both Text Continuation (TC) and Instruction Following (IF). The setup of TC is the same as in Sec.                  3.2                . For IF tasks, which are vital in chatbot and AI assistant applications, unlike TC, the goal for the LLM is to respond to questions or fulfill requests in the test cases. We adapt the prompt template from           (Taori et¬†al.,,             2023            )          to simulate a user-bot conversation, with a blank section for the target LLM to respond. Our target models for this task are           GPT2-alpaca          , a           GPT2          model fine-tuned with the           Alpaca          dataset           (Taori et¬†al.,,             2023            )          . To generate instruction-like test cases, we randomly sample combinations of instructions from the           Alpaca          as the context                          z                               ùëß                              z                       . Then we follow a similar process in TC, where                                   œÄ                         r                                                 subscript                            ùúã                            ùëü                                       \pi_{r}                       provokes toxic responses and                                   œÄ                         s                                                 subscript                            ùúã                            ùë†                                       \pi_{s}                       attempts to refine outputs from                                   œÄ                         r                                                 subscript                            ùúã                            ùëü                                       \pi_{r}                       for defense. A critical difference is that                                   x                         ‚àº                                   œÄ                            r                                                          similar-to                            ùë•                                       subscript                               ùúã                               ùëü                                                 x\sim\pi_{r}                       in this case does not include                                   z                         ‚àº                         ùíü                                                 similar-to                            ùëß                            ùíü                                       z\sim\mathcal{D}                       , therefore the target models                                   p                         t                                                 subscript                            ùëù                            ùë°                                       p_{t}                       cannot observe                          z                               ùëß                              z                       . We pack the generated prompt                                   x                         /                                   x                            ‚ãÜ                                                                            ùë•                                       superscript                               ùë•                               ‚ãÜ                                                 x/x^{\star}                       following the template in Appendix                  C                as target input. We evaluate the performance of both models on           Vanilla RL          (Eq.¬†(                  2                -                  3                ),                                             Œ≤                            2                                  =                         0                                                                              subscript                               ùõΩ                               2                                      0                                       \beta_{2}=0                       ),           RL+TDiv          (as in           (Casper et¬†al.,,             2023            )          ) and           RL+Curiosity          (Eq.¬†(                  2                -                  3                )) settings. Each experiments are evaluated with five random seeds per method. Detailed parameter settings can be found in Tab.                  4                -                  5                , Appendix                  D                .

Setup.          We employ the same setups for TC and IF as detailed in Sec.                  3.2                and Sec.                  3.3                . As empirically shown in Sec.                  3.3                , RL+Curiosity works the best in terms of training metric                                   R                         mae                                                 subscript                            ùëÖ                            mae                                       R_{\mathrm{mae}}                       , thus we set the curiosity approach as a baseline for evaluating three different value head strategies. Specifically, we benchmark the performance of red team-sentinel framework on           Independent          (Eq.¬†(                  4                )),           Centralized          (Eq.¬†(                  5                )), and           Partially Shared          (Eq.¬†(                  6                )) settings, evaluating each method on                          5                               5                              5                       random seeds. Parameter configurations are in Tab.                  4                -                  5                , Appendix                  D                .

Please refer to Table.¬†(               4             -               9             ) for detailed parameter configurations for all experiments provided in the main paper. The footnotes are links to models and datasets that are specified in the tables. All experiments are executed under CPU: AMD EPYC 7452 32-Core Processor and GPU: 3                      √ó                                             \times                   NVIDIA A100-PCIE-40GB.

We employ the vaniila           Curiosity          and           Curiosity          +           Partially Shared          (tagged with                          ‚Ä†                               ‚Ä†                              {\dagger}                       ) setting. Similarly to the description in Sec.                  3.3                , we employ the           Alpaca          corpus to trigger the red-teaming prompt. We detail the parameter configurations in Tab.                  6                -                  7                , Appendix                  D                .

references: Since the scale of           GPT2          is relatively small, we also demonstrate the efficacy of our approach against larger models like           Llama-2-7B-Chat          and           GPT-3.5-Turbo          (                          ‚àº                               similar-to                              \sim                       175B), without actually fine-tuning the large model. We employ the vaniila           Curiosity          and           Curiosity          +           Partially Shared          (tagged with                          ‚Ä†                               ‚Ä†                              {\dagger}                       ) setting. Similarly to the description in Sec.                  3.3                , we employ the           Alpaca          corpus to trigger the red-teaming prompt. We detail the parameter configurations in Tab.                  6                -                  7                , Appendix                  D                .

references: Text-to-image is an emerging application in generative models with safety concerns akin to those in text-to-text applications. Studies           (Rando et¬†al.,,             2022            ; Hong et¬†al.,,             2024            )          use red-teaming to probe what prompts trigger text-to-image models to generate harmful content,           e.g.,          not-safe-for-work (NSFW) images. We study if our sentinel approach can neutralize such a toxic prompt trigger and elicit safe images from the target model. We use           MagicPromptGPT2          as                                   œÄ                         r                                                 subscript                            ùúã                            ùëü                                       \pi_{r}                       and                                   œÄ                         s                                                 subscript                            ùúã                            ùë†                                       \pi_{s}                       , and use           stable-diffusion-2.1                (Rombach et¬†al.,,             2022            )          as target model. We employ the           nsfw_image_detection          as the reward function. The corpus for red-teaming is the           Stable-Diffusion-Prompts          , where we randomly sample                          1024                               1024                              1024                       combinations with                          2                               2                              2                       example prompts each. We use                                   œÄ                         r                                                 subscript                            ùúã                            ùëü                                       \pi_{r}                       and                                   œÄ                         s                                                 subscript                            ùúã                            ùë†                                       \pi_{s}                       to perform continuation on the input prompts, then feed the outputs to                                   stable-diffusion-2.1                         +                         classifier                                                                              stable-diffusion-2.1                                                 classifier                                                 \texttt{stable-diffusion-2.1}+\text{classifier}                       . Detailed parameter configurations are in Tab.                  8                , Appendix                  D                . Fig.                  8                illustrates the prompts generated by red team and sentinel, and their respective induced images. We observe that even with prior instruction requesting the generation of NSFW images, the sentinel model is still able to derive prompts that lead to SFW content. The substantially low percentage of NSFW responses with threshold                                                   >                         0                                                                   absent                            0                                       >0                       in the right charts (ii) also indicates the effectiveness of our approach at text-to-image tasks.

references: Using the script provided in the TRL toxicity repository, we compare our method to           direct detoxification          on the           wiki_toxic          evaluation dataset. The baselines are pretrained           GPT          s of different sizes, and their detoxified versions fine-tuned on           RealToxicityPrompts                (             Gehman et¬†al., 2020b,            )          dataset. Instead of tuning the victims directly with toxic prompts, we employ the sentinel                                   œÄ                         s                                                 subscript                            ùúã                            ùë†                                       \pi_{s}                       as the prefix model before target models and only tune                                   œÄ                         s                                                 subscript                            ùúã                            ùë†                                       \pi_{s}                       with PPO. No red team in this experiment since           (             Gehman et¬†al., 2020b,            )          is already toxic. We initialize                                   œÄ                         s                                                 subscript                            ùúã                            ùë†                                       \pi_{s}                       as           GPT-Neo-125M          . For models without a sentinel, we allow a maximum of                          30                               30                              30                       new tokens as output. For sentinel-assisted models, we restrict                          15                               15                              15                       maximum tokens for both the sentinel and target models, then concatenate the outputs for training/eval. We measure the toxicity score of outputs using the toxicity metric of the huggingface           evaluate          . Detailed parameter configurations are in Tab.                  9                , Appendix                  D                . We report the toxicity score of                          400                               400                              400                       sampled examples in Tab.                  2                . Sentinel-assisted models have better capabilities in reducing the toxicity score of generated text compared to direct-detoxified counterparts. The score gaps between our methods and baselines are clear across all model sizes, while for directly detoxified ones, the gaps are clear for smaller models but less so for the 6B model.

Please refer to Table.¬†(               4             -               9             ) for detailed parameter configurations for all experiments provided in the main paper. The footnotes are links to models and datasets that are specified in the tables. All experiments are executed under CPU: AMD EPYC 7452 32-Core Processor and GPU: 3                      √ó                                             \times                   NVIDIA A100-PCIE-40GB.
